awd_titl_txt: Continuous Manufacturing of Lead-free Halide Perovskite Nanocrystals Using a Microreactor System
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant supports research that advances knowledge to manufacture systems such as high efficiency solar cells, affordable photovoltaics, flexible color displays and biosensors more quickly, less expensively and free of the lead that results from more traditional manufacturing approaches.  Lead-free metal halide perovskite nanocrystals emit light from the ultraviolet to the visible. Their wide use is dependent on the development of techniques for their scalable, low cost manufacturing. They are also candidates for replacement of lead-based perovskites, which are toxic. Most methods to manufacture perovskite nanocrystals are based on single batch approach, which has limited production capacity and considerable product variability.  Research here will support a continuous manufacturing process.  The ability to manufacture semiconductor nanocrystals in microfluidic-microreactor systems enables their fabrication with the desired size, shape and properties, thus, accelerating their applications in a variety of industries. The successful development of a scalable method to manufacture high-quality lead-free halide perovskite nanocrystals enables the development of continuously manufactured lead-free metal halide perovskite nanocrystals that leads to progress in the fundamental science of inorganic semiconductors. The results from this research help maintain and enhance U.S. competitiveness and leadership in these technologies, thus contributing to the nation's prosperity. The multidisciplinary nature of this research prepares the needed future workforce for U.S. industries with knowledge and skills in advanced materials and manufacturing. Special efforts are focused on the participation and training of women and under-represented minorities.

Using microfluidic-microreactor systems can overcome the difficulty in controlling the processing parameters, such as, temperature, time and local concentration for the fabrication of perovskite nanocrystals in the single batch methods and offer a possible approach to manufacture them with very short reaction time and high throughput. The lack of an understanding of the thermodynamics and kinetics controlling the formation and growth of nanocrystals in a fluidic system has hindered the development of microfluidic-microreactor systems to produce monodispersed nanocrystals of the same geometrical shapes. This research is to develop a polytetrafluoroethylene-based microreactor in a microfluidic system with in-line monitoring for continuous fabrication of metal halide perovskite nanocrystals and to investigate the fundamental mechanisms controlling their formation and growth. The research team establishes correlations between the processing parameters, such as, concentration, temperature, residence time and flow rate, and perovskite nanocrystal characteristics, such as, morphology and size. The team develops numerical models that can quantitatively analyze the growth of semiconductor nanocrystals in the microreactor system. These correlations provide fundamental understanding of the kinetics controlling the size distribution and morphologies of nanocrystals and help optimize the microreactor design for the scalable manufacturing of high-quality perovskite nanocrystals.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF KENTUCKY RESEARCH FOUNDATION, THE

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on advancing knowledge to manufacture metal halide perovskite nanocrystals, which leads to the progress of fundamental science of inorganic semiconductor nanocrystals. Metal halide perovskite nanocrystals are light-emitting semiconductor nanocrystals under the irradiation of ultraviolet light. This project provides the necessary foundation from which the scalable nanomanufacturing of lead-free halide perovskite nanocrystals of high quality at low cost can be developed to meet the needs for the applications of metal halide perovskite nanocrystals in solar cells, catalysts, light-emitting devices and photodetectors for a variety of industries, including solar energy, optoelectronics, bioimaging and biosensing.

This project has developed a PTFE-based microfluidic system, which was used to synthesize Cs2SnI6 microcrystals with water as the sole carrier fluid. Cs2SnI6 nanocrystals are produced from the Cs2SnI6 microcrystals in hexane at room temperature. The highest photoluminescence quantum yield (PLQY) of the liquid solution of Cs2SnI6 nanocrystals is 13.4%, and the as-synthesized Cs2SnI6 nanocrystals retain a stable PLQY over a period of 60 days. Using the microfluidic system, 0.06 g dry Cs2SnI6 microcrystals were produced within 8 min with a production rate of 0.45 g/h.

This project has developed green-route approaches for the synthesis of lead-free double perovskite Cs2SnI6, CsPbBr3 and organic-inorganic hybrid MAPbBr3 (MA = CH3NH3) perovskite microcrystals with water as the sole solvent. Sonicating the prepared microcrystals in an organic solvent, such as toluene or hexane, at room temperature produces corresponding nanocrystals. Such an approach is cost-effective and eliminates the use of toxic, volatile organic solvent in preparation of the precursor solution for the synthesis of halide perovskite nanocrystals for the applications in optoelectronics and solar cells.  

A PTFE-based microfluidic system was developed and used to produce CsPbBr3 nanocrystals in a temperature range of 30 to 90 ?C via an antisolvent method. A simple relation is established between the bandgap (the PL peak wavelength) of semiconductor nanocrystals and the total flow rate without the contribution of Coulomb interaction to the effect of quantum confinement for the synthesis of semiconductor nanocrystals in a microfluid system. The growth behavior of the CsPbBr3 nanocrystals in the microfluidic system was analyzed by using this simple relation, and the square of the average size of the CsPbBr3 nanocrystals is found to be proportional to the growth time. This simple relation can be likely used to predict the average size of halide perovskite nanocrystals formed by using microfluidic systems.

This project has fully or partially supported four Ph.D. students. One of them succeeded in defending his PhD thesis in 2022. Eleven undergraduate students and a high school student had participated in the research on the syntheses of halide perovskite nanocrystals and TiO2 nanotubes, finite element simulation, nanoindentation and machine learning. Seven of them are women, a group significantly underrepresented in engineering fields. The project generated new knowledge about the manufacturing of halide perovskite nanocrystals, resulting in 1 Utility Patent Application, 17 peer-reviewed articles including papers in ACS Sustainable Chemistry & Engineering, Nanoscale, Lab on Chip, Langmuir, Physical Chemistry Chemical Physics, Nanotechnology, Advanced Science, and Chemical Engineering Journal, and 5 peer-reviewed conference presentations.

 


Last Modified: 07/09/2023
Modified by: Fuqian Yang
